terms.definition: Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted by a service provider and accessed via the internet
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, ensuring users always access the most current version
Safety Data Sheets - standardized documents that provide detailed information about chemical substances, including hazards, handling procedures, and emergency measures
Standard Operating Procedures - detailed written instructions that describe how to perform routine tasks or processes consistently and safely
The ability for multiple users to simultaneously work on and edit the same document with changes visible instantly to all participants
A system that stores all organizational documents in a single, unified location for easy access, organization, and control
Pre-designed document formats that provide a standardized structure and layout for creating consistent documentation
Pre-programmed sequences of tasks that execute automatically based on specific triggers or conditions, reducing manual effort
Enterprise Resource Planning - integrated software systems that manage and automate core business processes across an organization
A software design that can efficiently handle increasing amounts of data, users, or functionality without performance degradation
The process of quickly locating and accessing specific documents from a repository using search functions or organizational systems
The process of ensuring that business operations and documentation meet all applicable laws, regulations, and industry standards
The ability of software systems to connect and work together seamlessly, sharing data and functionality
A software solution specifically designed for creating, managing, organizing, and sharing various types of business documents and content
